<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>Today is Columbus Day, or as it’s increasingly known, Indigenous Peoples’ Day. In 1989, South Dakota became the first state to swap out a celebration of Christopher Columbus to honor Native Americans who were subjected to European colonial rule for centuries. Many states, cities, and universities have also made the switch in recent years.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, it remains a federal holiday, which means the bond markets are closed and so are most banks. Whether you’re working today or relishing the final few hours of a three-day weekend, we hope it’s a good one.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/11/nba-bubble-experiment-passes-flying-colors?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Bubble That Never Popped
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="NBA Finals" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNzQ1L25iYV9maW5hbHMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Douglas P. DeFelice/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last night, the Los Angeles Lakers closed out the Miami Heat to win the NBA championship, ending the weirdest—but most impactful—season in league history.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The legacy: </strong>The NBA's coronavirus "bubble" will be remembered as one of the most impressive business achievements of the pandemic.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>The league paused its season on March 11, that <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/an-oral-history-of-the-day-everything-changed-coronavirus/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wild day</a> the WHO declared Covid-19 a global pandemic, the Dow crashed 1,465 points, and Tom Hanks announced he tested positive. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As states started to ease business restrictions, sports leagues that had paused their seasons were figuring out how to restart safely. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver, partnering with the players association, went for a moonshot with a self-contained “<a href="https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/30055011/everything-happened-nba-bubble?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">bubble</a>” at Florida’s ESPN Wide World of Sports Complex.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>To keep basketball players in and the virus out, the league implemented super-strict </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/16/sports/basketball/nba-bubble-coronavirus-disney-world.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">health protocols</a></span><span>. Family and friends couldn’t even arrive until the second round of the playoffs.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Major storylines</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Following the social unrest in the spring, the NBA had made Black Lives Matter messaging a focal point of the restart—but no one was prepared when players refused to play following the police shooting of a Black man in Kenosha, WI. The strike was “historic, front-page news that connected sports, politics, racial protests, and labor relations,” <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/10/10/nba-bubble-farewell/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writes</a> the Washington Post’s Ben Golliver.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Players </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/08/28/nba-playoffs-return-multi-day-strike-organized-players?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">returned to the court</a></span><span> a few days later after securing commitments from the league. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">New entrepreneurs emerged.</strong> Heat star Jimmy Butler started a coffee shop, Big Face Coffee, out of his hotel room. He appeared to <a href="https://www.foodandwine.com/news/jimmy-butler-miami-heat-coffee-shop-nba-bubble?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">file three trademarks</a> for the brand in September.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">It wasn’t a complete success story. </strong>The NBA, like many other sports leagues, is suffering from <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/media/2020/10/08/pandemic-why-tv-ratings-sports-have-been-down-since-returning/5913720002/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">awful TV ratings</a>. Experts think there are a number of contributing factors, but they point to the crowded fall sports calendar as the most likely cause of the viewership dip. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the bubble worked this season, but there’s another one right around the corner—and the pandemic isn’t going away. Adam Silver’s follow-up act may be more difficult than the first.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MARKETS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/11/wall-street-chinese-currency-price-biden-victory?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Markets Try on Their Pundit Bow Ties
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The U.S. presidential election is 22 canvassing-call-filled days out. Market watchers are playing Nate Silver to game out the polls...which are currently leaning toward a Biden victory. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Biden won in 86 out of the 100 outcomes simulated by Silver’s </span><span><a href="https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">FiveThirtyEight</a></span><span> website. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">In equities: </strong>Wall Street <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-11/jpmorgan-says-u-s-capital-gains-tax-hike-may-briefly-hit-stocks?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">is down</a> with aviators in the Oval, despite initial worries about higher capital gains taxes under a President Joe. JPMorgan strategists are pricing in a temporary drag on stocks in Q4 in the event of a Biden win, followed by a recovery next year. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Why the optimism? With bonds and cash offering only razor-thin or even negative yields, stocks remain the only viable option for investors to make real cheddar. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Under a Biden administration, Raymond James forecasts an exodus out of tech stocks and into sectors favored by additional coronavirus stimulus packages. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">In currencies: </strong>Chinese investors are also <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-09/chinese-yuan-soars-as-policy-makers-usher-on-blue-wave-rally?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">bullish on Biden</a>. The onshore yuan rallied the most in 13+ years last week in hopes of a “blue wave” of Democrat victories diminishing trade tensions.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPACE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/11/virgin-orbit-raise-much-200-million?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Virgin Orbit Needs Help to Make Its Rockets Go Woosh
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A Virgin Orbit rocket " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNzQ0L3Zpcmdpbl9vcmJpdC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Virgin Orbit/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Richard Branson’s Virgin Orbit is looking to raise between $150 million and $200 million at a roughly $1 billion valuation, the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/richard-bransons-virgin-orbit-seeks-1-billion-valuation-in-fundraising-11602403201?mod=business_lead_pos2&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">WSJ reported</a> yesterday. LionTree Advisors and Perella Weinberg will help it gin up the cash. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Nope, not Virgin Galactic—this is the other one.</strong> Virgin Galactic does space tourism for people, and Virgin Orbit does space tourism for satellites; it launches smaller satellites into orbit for government and commercial customers. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Or...it hopes to eventually. It hasn’t yet put a payload into orbit, and an initial demonstration flight in May failed. Analysts estimate that the company has spent at least $400 million in development, </span><span><a href="https://arstechnica.com/science/2020/10/why-has-virgin-orbit-spent-so-much-on-its-rocket-and-will-it-ever-be-profitable/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">much more</a></span><span> than rivals. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Virgin Orbit also takes a different approach to launches. It’s more nimble, launching satellites from moving aircraft rather than the ground. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Pre-Covid, the space space was already a tricky one for startups. Then, when the pandemic hit, investors got even stingier. But interest in Virgin Orbit’s flexible launch system is creeping back. </p>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/11/retailers-leverage-curbside-pickup-ahead-fall-sales-events?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">

Curbside Enthusiasm
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Curbside pickup at Home Depot" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNzQzL2N1cmJzaWRlX3BpY2t1cF9hdF9ob21lX2RlcG90LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Creative Touch Imaging Ltd./NurPhoto via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This week, retailers including Target and Walmart are launching big sales events to compete against Amazon Prime Day, which starts tomorrow.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Their <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/11/walmart-target-try-to-beat-amazon-with-curbside-pickup.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">secret weapon</a>, per CNBC? Curbside pickup. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What that is: </strong>When you place an online order, then get in your car and drive to the store’s parking lot to pick it up. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s been a game-changer for retailers during the pandemic, the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/09/business/retailers-curbside-pickup.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">NYT reports</a>. Target’s curbside sales increased more than 700% last quarter, and of Best Buy’s nearly $5 billion in Q2 online revenue, 41% came from pickup orders.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Why is it so popular?<strong style="color:#000"></strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">For customers: </strong></span><span>As much as having an item shipped to you is convenient, you can always get something faster if you go to the store.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">For retailers: </strong></span><span>The “last mile” of delivery is a notoriously difficult (and expensive) logistical nut to crack. With curbside pickup, customers do that for you.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the big question is whether curbside will remain popular when the pandemic is over and browsing in a store doesn’t require battle gear.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Start Talking
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Every Monday, we curate a handful of balanced resources about a hot-button business issue and encourage you to discuss with friends, family, or coworkers. </em><em><br></em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This week’s topic: </strong>Months into their tug-of-war over a new pandemic relief package, lawmakers and the White House are continuing to butt heads over how much federal aid to give cash-strapped state and local governments. Of the $2.6 trillion the government has spent on economic relief, <a href="https://www.pandemicoversight.gov/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$291 billion</a> has gone to state, local, and tribal governments. Is that enough? </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Where states are losing their money (</span><span><a href="https://budget.house.gov/publications/report/state-and-local-governments-are-dire-need-federal-relief?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">House Committee on the Budget</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Just how much is Covid-19 impacting state and local revenues? (</span><span><a href="https://www.brookings.edu/blog/up-front/2020/09/24/how-much-is-covid-19-hurting-state-and-local-revenues/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Brookings</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>What Democrats and Republicans are fighting over (</span><span><a href="https://thehill.com/policy/finance/515221-discord-over-state-and-local-funds-plagues-coronavirus-talks?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Hill</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The National Governors Association has repeatedly asked the federal government for an additional $500 billion (</span><span><a href="https://statescoop.com/state-and-local-governments-plead-again-as-federal-pandemic-relief-stalls/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">StateScoop</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>State and local governments are fighting over where the money flows (</span><span><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/07/13/cities-states-cares-act/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">WaPo</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
</ul>

Most economies around the world have rebounded slightly off their lows, but they’re nowhere near pre-Covid output levels.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eStimulus: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSorry for sounding like a broken record, but lawmakers failed to make progress on a new coronavirus aid package this weekend. Both Republicans and Democrats said they \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-usa-congress/trumps-stimulus-proposal-draws-opposition-from-congressional-democrats-and-republicans-idUSKBN26V0SR?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewouldn’t support\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the White House’s $1.8 trillion proposal.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eStocks: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eDespite those headlines, stocks are coming off their \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/08/stock-market-futures-open-to-close-news.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebest week\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e since the summer. Starting this week: Q3 earnings season.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!-- END MARKETS --\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE ---\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"c6 \" style=\"margin-bottom:7px\"\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth class=\"card\" style=\"text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px\"\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding: 15px;\"\u003e\n\u003ch3 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nSPORTS \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/11/nba-bubble-experiment-passes-flying-colors?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nThe Bubble That Never Popped\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"NBA Finals\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNzQ1L25iYV9maW5hbHMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eDouglas P. DeFelice/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast night, the Los Angeles Lakers closed out the Miami Heat to win the NBA championship, ending the weirdest—but most impactful—season in league history.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe legacy: \u003c/strong\u003eThe NBA's coronavirus \"bubble\" will be remembered as one of the most impressive business achievements of the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eThe league paused its season on March 11, that \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.com/story/an-oral-history-of-the-day-everything-changed-coronavirus/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewild day\u003c/a\u003e the WHO declared Covid-19 a global pandemic, the Dow crashed 1,465 points, and Tom Hanks announced he tested positive. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs states started to ease business restrictions, sports leagues that had paused their seasons were figuring out how to restart safely. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver, partnering with the players association, went for a moonshot with a self-contained “\u003ca href=\"https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/30055011/everything-happened-nba-bubble?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebubble\u003c/a\u003e” at Florida’s ESPN Wide World of Sports Complex.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eTo keep basketball players in and the virus out, the league implemented super-strict \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/16/sports/basketball/nba-bubble-coronavirus-disney-world.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehealth protocols\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. Family and friends couldn’t even arrive until the second round of the playoffs.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eMajor storylines\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFollowing the social unrest in the spring, the NBA had made Black Lives Matter messaging a focal point of the restart—but no one was prepared when players refused to play following the police shooting of a Black man in Kenosha, WI. The strike was “historic, front-page news that connected sports, politics, racial protests, and labor relations,” \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/10/10/nba-bubble-farewell/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrites\u003c/a\u003e the Washington Post’s Ben Golliver.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003ePlayers \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/08/28/nba-playoffs-return-multi-day-strike-organized-players?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereturned to the court\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e a few days later after securing commitments from the league. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNew entrepreneurs emerged.\u003c/strong\u003e Heat star Jimmy Butler started a coffee shop, Big Face Coffee, out of his hotel room. He appeared to \u003ca href=\"https://www.foodandwine.com/news/jimmy-butler-miami-heat-coffee-shop-nba-bubble?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efile three trademarks\u003c/a\u003e for the brand in September.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIt wasn’t a complete success story. \u003c/strong\u003eThe NBA, like many other sports leagues, is suffering from \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/media/2020/10/08/pandemic-why-tv-ratings-sports-have-been-down-since-returning/5913720002/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eawful TV ratings\u003c/a\u003e. Experts think there are a number of contributing factors, but they point to the crowded fall sports calendar as the most likely cause of the viewership dip. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe bubble worked this season, but there’s another one right around the corner—and the pandemic isn’t going away. Adam Silver’s follow-up act may be more difficult than the first.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe U.S. presidential election is 22 canvassing-call-filled days out. Market watchers are playing Nate Silver to game out the polls...which are currently leaning toward a Biden victory. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBiden won in 86 out of the 100 outcomes simulated by Silver’s \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eFiveThirtyEight\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e website. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIn equities: \u003c/strong\u003eWall Street \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-11/jpmorgan-says-u-s-capital-gains-tax-hike-may-briefly-hit-stocks?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eis down\u003c/a\u003e with aviators in the Oval, despite initial worries about higher capital gains taxes under a President Joe. JPMorgan strategists are pricing in a temporary drag on stocks in Q4 in the event of a Biden win, followed by a recovery next year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhy the optimism? With bonds and cash offering only razor-thin or even negative yields, stocks remain the only viable option for investors to make real cheddar. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eUnder a Biden administration, Raymond James forecasts an exodus out of tech stocks and into sectors favored by additional coronavirus stimulus packages. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIn currencies: \u003c/strong\u003eChinese investors are also \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-09/chinese-yuan-soars-as-policy-makers-usher-on-blue-wave-rally?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebullish on Biden\u003c/a\u003e. The onshore yuan rallied the most in 13+ years last week in hopes of a “blue wave” of Democrat victories diminishing trade tensions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable Curbside pickup. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat that is: \u003c/strong\u003eWhen you place an online order, then get in your car and drive to the store’s parking lot to pick it up. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s been a game-changer for retailers during the pandemic, the \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/09/business/retailers-curbside-pickup.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNYT reports\u003c/a\u003e. Target’s curbside sales increased more than 700% last quarter, and of Best Buy’s nearly $5 billion in Q2 online revenue, 41% came from pickup orders.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhy is it so popular?\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFor customers: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAs much as having an item shipped to you is convenient, you can always get something faster if you go to the store.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFor retailers: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe “last mile” of delivery is a notoriously difficult (and expensive) logistical nut to crack. With curbside pickup, customers do that for you.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe big question is whether curbside will remain popular when the pandemic is over and browsing in a store doesn’t require battle gear.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F10%2F11%2Fretailers-leverage-curbside-pickup-ahead-fall-sales-events\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block;
